lines.text: Enter LAUNCELOT

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me saying to me Gobbo, Launcelot Gobbo, good Launcelot, or good Gobbo, or good Launcelot Gobbo, use your legs, take the start, run away. My conscience says No take heed, honest Launcelot take heed, honest Gobbo, or, as aforesaid, honest Launcelot Gobbo do not run scorn running with thy heels. Well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack: Via! says the fiend away! says the fiend for the heavens, rouse up a brave mind, says the fiend, and run. Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest mans son, or rather an honest womans son for, indeed, my father did something smack, something grow to, he had a kind of taste well, my conscience says Launcelot, budge not. Budge, says the fiend. Budge not, says my conscience. Conscience, say I, you counsel well  Fiend, say I, you counsel well: to be ruled by my conscience, I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil and, to run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself. Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnal and, in my conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more friendly counsel: I will run, fiend my heels are at your command I will run.
Enter Old GOBBO, with a basket

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to master Jews

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: [Aside]  O heavens, this is my truebegotten father! who, being more than sandblind, highgravel blind, knows me not: I will try confusions with him.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to master Jews

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but, at the next turning of all, on your left marry, at the very next turning, turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jews house.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: By Gods sonties, twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell me whether one Launcelot, that dwells with him, dwell with him or no

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Talk you of young Master Launcelot Mark me now now will I raise the waters. Talk you of young Master Launcelot
Aside

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: No master, sir, but a poor mans son: his father, though I say it, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Well, let his father be what a will, we talk of young Master Launcelot.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Your worships friend and Launcelot, sir.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Of Launcelot, ant please your mastership.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master Launcelot, father for the young gentleman, according to Fates and Destinies and such odd sayings, the Sisters Three and such branches of learning, is indeed deceased, or, as you would say in plain terms, gone to heaven.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Marry, God forbid! the boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovelpost, a staff or a prop Do you know me, father

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman: but, I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Do you not know me, father

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Alack, sir, I am sandblind I know you not.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Nay, indeed, if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me: it is a wise father that knows his own child. Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son: give me your blessing: truth will come to light murder cannot be hid long a mans son may, but at the length truth will out.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Pray you, sir, stand up: I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Pray you, lets have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing: I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: I cannot think you are my son.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: I know not what I shall think of that: but I am Launcelot, the Jews man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Her name is Margery, indeed: Ill be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood. Lord worshipped might he be! what a beard hast thou got! thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my fillhorse has on his tail.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: It should seem, then, that Dobbins tail grows backward: I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy master agree I have brought him a present. How gree you now

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Well, well: but, for mine own part, as I have set up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have run some ground. My masters a very Jew: give him a present! give him a halter: I am famished in his service you may tell every finger I have with my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come: give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who, indeed, gives rare new liveries: if I serve not him, I will run as far as God has any ground. O rare fortune! here comes the man: to him, father for I am a Jew, if I serve the Jew any longer.
Enter BASSANIO, with LEONARDO and other followers

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: You may do so but let it be so hasted that supper be ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See these letters delivered put the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.
Exit a Servant

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: To him, father.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: God bless your worship!

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: Gramercy! wouldst thou aught with me

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: Heres my son, sir, a poor boy,

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jews man that would, sir, as my father shall specify

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Indeed, the short and the long is, I serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: His master and he, saving your worships reverence, are scarce catercousins

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being, I hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon your worship, and my suit is

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your worship shall know by this honest old man and, though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: One speak for both. What would you

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Serve you, sir.

lines.speaker: gobbo
lines.text: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: I know thee well thou hast obtaind thy suit: Shylock thy master spoke with me this day, And hath preferrd thee, if it be preferment To leave a rich Jews service, to become The follower of so poor a gentleman.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of God, sir, and he hath enough.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: Thou speakst it well. Go, father, with thy son. Take leave of thy old master and inquire My lodging out. Give him a livery More guarded than his fellows: see it done.

lines.speaker: launcelot
lines.text: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no I have neer a tongue in my head. Well, if any man in Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear upon a book, I shall have good fortune. Go to, heres a simple line of life: heres a small trifle of wives: alas, fifteen wives is nothing! eleven widows and nine maids is a simple comingin for one man: and then to scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a featherbed here are simple scapes. Well, if Fortune be a woman, shes a good wench for this gear. Father, come Ill take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling of an eye.
Exeunt Launcelot and Old Gobbo

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this: These things being bought and orderly bestowd, Return in haste, for I do feast tonight My bestesteemd acquaintance: hie thee, go.

lines.speaker: leonardo
lines.text: My best endeavours shall be done herein.
Enter GRATIANO

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Where is your master

lines.speaker: leonardo
lines.text: Yonder, sir, he walks.
Exit

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Signior Bassanio!

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: Gratiano!

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: I have a suit to you.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: You have obtaind it.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: You must not deny me: I must go with you to Belmont.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: Why then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults But where thou art not known, why, there they show Something too liberal. Pray thee, take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior I be misconstrued in the place I go to, And lose my hopes.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Signior Bassanio, hear me: If I do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect and swear but now and then, Wear prayerbooks in my pocket, look demurely, Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh and say amen, Use all the observance of civility, Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam, never trust me more.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: Well, we shall see your bearing.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Nay, but I bar tonight: you shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.

lines.speaker: bassanio
lines.text: No, that were pity: I would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends That purpose merriment. But fare you well: I have some business.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: And I must to Lorenzo and the rest: But we will visit you at suppertime.
Exeunt
